Award.AwardTitle: Clifford Lectures on Algebraic Groups: Structure and Actions
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports participation in the conference "Clifford Lectures on Algebraic Groups: Structure and Actions" held March 2-5, 2015 at Tulane University in New Orleans, Louisiana. The conference will stimulate research on the interplay between geometry and number theory. An important goal of this conference is to prepare graduate students for research in the areas of algebraic group theory, algebraic geometry, and number theory, in particular to suggest thesis projects. The Clifford Lecture Series is a medium-sized conference and it provides ample opportunities for its participants to interact with each other. This atmosphere is invaluable especially for graduate students and junior researchers new to the field. It is anticipated that the meeting will lead to active collaborations between the participants, including students and faculty from non-Ph.D.-granting institutions.

The main speaker is Michel Brion (University of Grenoble, France). His talks focus on the structure and actions of algebraic groups over arbitrary fields, the applications of algebraic group theory to algebraic geometry (automorphism groups and their birational analogues) and number theory, and various aspects of homogeneous varieties and their equivariant embeddings (algebra, algebraic combinatorics, geometry).

Conference web site: http://tulane.edu/sse/math/news/clifford-lectures-march-2015.cfm

POR.DRECONTENT:
Funded by the National Science Foundation and the Mathematics Department at Tulane University gave the mathematical community a timely opportunity to enhance the visibility of the highly interdisciplinary field of algebraic groups and actions. It not only provided a unique opportunity to bring together some of the principal investigators, junior researchers, and graduate students in algebraic group theory, algebraic geometry, and representation theory, but also increased the synthesis of these areas. Currently, we are in the process of publishing the proceedings of the workshop as a volume in the Proceedings of Symposia in Pure Mathematics series of the American Mathematical Society. Moreover, after getting guidance from some senior researchers, some graduate students made significant progress towards solving their thesis problems during the conference. These advancements attracted new students to work on the projects developed during the workshop. 


The speaker list was 

 

(1) Michel Brion (Uni. Grenoble) 

(2) David Anderson (The Ohio State University)

(3) Jeremy Blanc (Uni. Basel)

(4) Brian Conrad (Stanford)

(5) Alexander Merkurjev (UCLA)

(6) Gopal Prasad (U. Michigan)

(7) Zinovy Reichstein (U. British Columbia)


Brief descriptions of the talks are as follows. (Detailed information about the contents of the lectures (and more) can be found at http://dauns.math.tulane.edu/~mcan/Clifford.html)

1. The main speaker, Michel Brion has presented some fundamental results on the structure of algebraic groups and their actions on algebraic varieties. 

2. David Anderson explained some of the basic properties of the operational K-theory and showed how to use it to obtain new information about usual K-theory. He described the Riemann-Roch and equivariant localization theorems for operational theories, and concluded with applications to toric and spherical varieties.

3. Jeremy Blanc discussed the possible structure that we can put on the group Bir(X) of birational transformations of an algebraic variety X. 

4. Brian Conrad presented a variety of examples illustrating how the notion of pseudo-reductivity can be useful, and how these objects are necessary for studying reductive groups.He introduced the ”standard construction” of pseudo-reductive groups and discussed some of their general features (such as root groups, root systems, and pseudo-parabolic subgroups).

5. Alexander Merkurjev gave basic definitions of a cohomological invariant and a classifying space of an algebraic group. He showed how to determine the degree 3 invariants of split reductive groups. As an application he showed how unramified invariants can be used to detect non-rationality property of classifying spaces of algebraic groups.
